heading: stocks up on 'january effect'
subheading: investors spill back into the market with their pockets full and hopes high. add to that the arrival of the euro and some glowing internet news, and a rally is born. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: traders call it "the january effect," when investors spill back into the market after the holidays and begin throwing money at just about any stock in motion, optimistically hoping to latch onto the next big thing. factor in the arrival of the euro and continued good news from the internet front, and you have all the fixings for a solid start-of-the-year rally. the dow jones industrial average gained 101.70 points to 9283.13 in mid-afternoon trading monday, and the s&p 500 was 10.35 higher at 1239.58. the nasdaq composite index rose 33.85 to 2226.54, and the wired index was up 10.24 at 577.48."the seamless transition to the euro in europe is making for a lot of enthusiasm," said peter russ, chief investment strategist with laidlaw global securities. "people are very interested in companies with business on both sides of the atlantic."reflecting this enthusiasm, daimlerchrysler (dcx) climbed us$6.31 to $102.38, and mobile-phone giant nokia (nok/a) was $8.19 higher at $128.63. cable & wireless (cwp) advanced 63 cents to $37.38, boosted by having landed a five-year, $166 million contract to supply vodafone group, britain's leading wireless phone service provider, with additional capacity.internet stocks needed little incentive to resume their journey to a higher plane of existence. just about anything even remotely smelling like an e-commerce play found buyers after a new survey found that the average us online shopper spent $629 for goods and services last year, a twofold increase from the year before. more importantly, the majority of poll respondents said they expect to spend even more online this year.not surprisingly, amazon.com (amzn) jumped $18.75 to $340, and ebay (ebay) was up $6.25 at $247.50. yahoo (yhoo) rose $11.56 to $248.50, but america online (aol) slipped $5.13 to $150 even as it said its 15 million members accounted for $1.2 billion in online purchases over the holiday season. could it be that aol's lofty share price is starting to give investors a nosebleed?nah. despite a huge run-up in aol's valuation in recent months, most analysts still think the world's biggest online service remains in a unique position to capitalize on new net-related trends, whatever they might be.etrade group (egrp) took off like a rocket after announcing a two-for-one stock split for shareholders of record as of 15 january. the online broker said it wants its stock to remain affordable for new investors -- a pretty smooth line considering that investors will now be buying less with each share they add to their portfolio. etrade surged $7.59, or 16 percent, to $54.38.in tech, intel (intc) advanced $3.38 to $121.94 after introducing a pair of new processors, and compaq computer (cpq) was $1.31 higher at $43.31 as it rolled out a new pentium-powered server. dell computer (dell) gained 81 cents to $74, and microsoft (msft) was up $4.69 at $143.38.airtouch communications (ati), the world's biggest wireless phone company, fell $2.56 to $69.88 on confirmation that bell atlantic (bel) is negotiating to purchase the firm for about $43 billion in stock. a deal announcement could come as soon as this week. bell atlantic was 88 cents lower at $53.13.lastly, internet software maker spyglass (spyg) tumbled $6.50, or 30 percent, to $15.50 after warning that it will post a fiscal first-quarter loss of as much as 16 cents a share because of delays in receiving revenue from customers. analysts had been looking for a quarterly profit of 1 cent.
